data.title: Famous Birthdays on April 3
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 3rd of April. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on April 3.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 289

Igor Svyatoslavich, Ukrainian prince (d. 1202)

Philips III, King of France (1270-85), born in Poissy, France (d. 1285)

Henry IV of England

King of England and Lord of Ireland (1399-1413), born in Bolingbroke Castle, Lincolnshire, England

John III of Egmont [Jan van Egmond], Viceroy of Holland, born in Hattem, Netherlands (d. 1516)

Anne of France, French princess, daughter of King Louis XI and Regent of France (1483-91) for her brother King Charles VIII during his minority, born in Chateau of Genappe, Brabant, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1522)

Lieven van der Maude [Livius Ammonius], South Netherland poet and Carthusian monk, born in Ghent, Habsburg Netherlands (d. 1556)

Michael Neander, German mathematician and astronomer, born in Joachimsthal, Bohemia (d. 1581)

Giovanni Battista Massarengo, Italian composer, born in Parma, Duchy of Parma (d. c.1596)

George Herbert, English metaphysical poet (5 Mystical Songs), born in Montgomery, Wales (d. 1633)

William Smith, British composer of Anglican sacred choral works, baptized in Durham, England (d. 1645)

Antimo Liberati, Italian composer, born in Foligno, Umbria, Papal States (d. 1692)

Joseph François Salomon, French composer, born in Toulon, France (d. 1732)

Johann Valentin Rathgeber, German organist, Benedictine priest, choirmaster, and composer (Augsburger Tafel-Confect), born in Oberelsbach, Electorate of Bavaria, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1750)

Mark Catesby, English naturalist (Natural History of Carolina, Florida and the Bahama Islands) (d. 1749)

George Edwards, English naturalist and ornithologist (father of British ornithology), born in Stratford, Essex, England (d. 1773)

John Hanson, Continental Congressman, 1st US President under Articles of Confederation, born in Maryland (d. 1783)

1715 William Watson, English physician and scientist, born in London (d. 1787)

Elia van Vilnius [Elijahu ben Salomo Zalman], Latvian rabbi, born in Sialiec, Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (d. 1797)

Philippe-Lambert-Joseph Spruyt, Flemish painter and engraver, born in Ghent, Belgium (d. 1801)

Jean-Baptiste Lemoyne, French opera composer, born in Eymet, France (d. 1796)

Ferenc Verseghy, Hungarian poet and composer, born in Szolnok, Hungary (d. 1822)

John Abernethy, English surgeon, born in London, England (d. 1831)

Christian Günther von Bernstorff, Danish-Prussian statesman and diplomat, born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1835)

Theodoros Kolokotronis, Greek general and leader of the Greek War of Independence (1821-29), born in Ramοvouni, Messenia, Ottoman Empire (d. 1843)

Washington Irving

American author (Legend of Sleepy Hollow), born in New York City

Anne Lister, English diarist 'the 1st modern lesbian', born in Halifax, England (d. 1840)

Charles Wilkes

American Antarctic explorer and naval officer (Union Navy), born in New York City

Ivan Kireyevsky, Russian literary critic and philosopher, born in Moscow (d. 1856)

Louisa Maria, Queen of Belgium (1832-50), Wife of Leopold I), born in Château de Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (d. 1850)

Lorenzo Snow, 5th president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, born in Mantua, Ohio (d. 1901)

T. Pelham Dale, Anglican clergyman prosecuted for Ritualist practices in the 1870s, born in Greenwich (d. 1892)

Edward Everett Hale, American clergyman and author (Man without a Country), born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1909)

Boss Tweed

American politician and corrupt New York fraudster, born in New York City

Adolf Rzepko, Polish composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1892)

John Burroughs, American writer and nature enthusiast (Burroughs Medal namesake), born in Delaware County, New York (d. 1921)

Leon Michel Gambetta, French attorney and 37th Prime Minister of France (1881-82), born in Cahors, Kingdom of France (d. 1882)

Ulric Dahlgren, American Colonel (Union Army), born in Bucks County, Pennsylvania (d. 1864)

Frederik Willem van Eeden, Dutch utopian writer (Walden), born in Haarlem, Netherlands (d. 1932)

Henry Van de Velde, Flemish painter and architect (Art Nouveau), born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1957)

J. B. M. Hertzog

South African General and Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa (1924-39), born in Wellington, South Africa

Jose Juan Tablada, Mexican poet (El Florilegio), born in Mexico City (d. 1941)

1871 Mistinguett [Jeanne Florentine Bourgeois], French actress and singer (Moulin Rouge star), born in Enghien-les-Bains, Val-d'Oise, France (d. 1956)

Eduardo Sanchez de Fuentes, Cuban composer, born in Havana, Cuba (d. 1944)

Alcide de Gasperi, 30th Prime Minister of Italy (1945-53), born in Pieve Tesino, Tyrol, Austria-Hungary (d. 1954)

Jimmy Matthews, Australian cricket spin bowler (8 Tests, 16 wickets; Victoria; only player to take 2 hat-tricks in same Test 1912), born in Mount Gambier, Australia (d. 1943)

Homesick James [Williamson], American blues slide guitarist and singer (Elmore James band, 1955-62), born in Somerville, Tennessee (d. 2006) [date of birth variously reported as 1905, 1910, and 1914; surname also disputed]

Michael Woodruff, English surgeon and scientist (organ transplantation), born in Mill Hill, London (d. 2001)

1911 Stanislawa Walasiewicz [Stella Walsh], Polish-American athlete (Olympic gold 100m 1932), born in Wierzchownia, Poland (d. 1980)

George Sopkin, American cellist (Fine Arts Quartet, 1941-79), and teacher, born in Chicago, Ilinois (d. 2008)
